importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed on October 9, 2025, establishing a framework for the return of deceased hostages from Gaza to Israel, which directly triggers the events described in the article.

The transfer of two additional coffins containing the remains of deceased hostages occurred on October 21, 2025, marking the 14th and 15th such transfers since the ceasefire agreement began, highlighting ongoing challenges in compliance and recovery.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Under the Trump administration's ceasefire agreement, Hamas was required to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours of the ceasefire going into effect, a deadline that has been repeatedly challenged due to logistical and operational difficulties.

keyTakeAways: The Israeli military confirmed that two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred from Gaza into Israel on October 21, 2025, after being handed over by the Red Cross.

The bodies are being transported to the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, and if confirmed, will be the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be returned since the ceasefire agreement was signed on October 9.

Hamas has acknowledged the transfer schedule and said 'significant efforts and special equipment' are needed to recover bodies buried under rubble in Gaza, indicating persistent challenges in locating and retrieving all remains.
One previously handed-over body was not identified as an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible misidentification, with Israeli sources indicating it may have been an error rather than intentional.

The US Vice President, JD Vance, emphasized that returning the bodies is a top priority, describing the process as difficult and not something that will happen overnight, especially given that some remains are buried under thousands of pounds of rubble.

The transfer of the bodies occurred amid renewed tensions between Israel and Hamas, which both accused each other of ceasefire violations, adding political and humanitarian complexity to the situation.

The US administration has committed to supporting efforts to locate and return all deceased hostages, even if it takes time, underscoring international involvement in the humanitarian aspects of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is the primary recipient of the deceased hostages' remains and the central actor in the military and governmental response to the transfer, including coordination with the IDF and the Ministry of Health.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Palestinian militant group and political organization
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is responsible for the transfer of the bodies of deceased hostages under the ceasefire agreement, and its actions—including delays and misidentifications—are at the core of the article’s conflict and challenges.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Al-Qassam Brigades are specifically cited as having announced the scheduled transfer of the two coffins, indicating their operational role in the logistics of hostage remains recovery.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is directly involved in escorting the coffins into Israel and conducting security and coordination for the transfer, making it a key entity in the operational and security framework.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA jointly issued a statement with the IDF about the transfer, indicating its role in assessing the situation and monitoring Hamas compliance with the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Health (Israel)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ministry of Health confirmed the arrival of the bodies at the forensic institute, showing its role in public health and family notification protocols.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine (Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Medical and forensic research institution in Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This institution is where the identification procedures for the remains will take place, making it essential to the process of verifying and confirming identities.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross is cited as the custodian from which the coffins were handed over to Israeli forces, highlighting the role of international humanitarian actors in ceasefire logistics.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. government administration under former President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration proposed the ceasefire deal and is involved in overseeing its implementation, including public statements on the return of hostages and the complexity of recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Vice President under the Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance visited Israel and addressed the situation at a press conference, emphasizing the difficulty and urgency of recovering the bodies, especially those buried under rubble.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli military officer and one of the deceased hostages
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His identification as the 13th returned body confirms the pattern of identification and underscores the significance of each recovery in the broader context of the hostage crisis.

namedEntities.name: Ceasefire Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Agreement between Israel and Hamas to end hostilities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement mandates the return of deceased hostages within 72 hours and forms the legal and humanitarian basis for the transfer of the bodies described in the article.

namedEntities.name: Gaza
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Region in the Middle East where conflict and hostilities occurred
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Gaza is the location where the bodies were found and transferred from, and where Hamas is responsible for recovery and return operations under the ceasefire terms.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli military confirmed that two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred from Gaza into Israel on October 21, 2025, following a US-proposed ceasefire agreement signed on October 9. The bodies were handed over by the Red Cross and escorted by Israeli forces to the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification. This marks the 14th and 15th such transfers since the agreement. Hamas has acknowledged the transfer schedule but cited logistical challenges, including the need for special equipment to recover bodies buried under rubble, and one previously returned body was misidentified as not belonging to an Israeli hostage. The Israeli government and international actors, including the Trump administration and Vice President JD Vance, have emphasized the difficulty and importance of returning the bodies to families, calling it a humanitarian priority that will not happen overnight.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages’ Bodies Cross Into Israel
